Oh my, no one has suggested we "suicide proof" the world-- just address areas that ARE preventable with reasonable measures, and in those areas that are proven, demonstrated problem Spots.Â Â Such as the gorges at Cornell.Â This problem did not begin in 2010.Â This isÂ not new news for Cornell. Interestingly, the only references I could find to indicate that Cornell's suicide rate is in the norm are statements that come from their own PR and counseling departments.Â Â It seems to Depend on the snapshot in time from which you cull the data. Â Nonetheless, the gorges are a choice for the impulse driven suicidal student, so why not do something about a known, proven risk factor?Â Â
Highway overpasses frequently have high fences, in my area many pedestrian bridges are completely enclosed.Â Yes, indeed, there is precedent in the wider world to apply suicide prevention strategies.
No, we cannot prevent every suicide or protect every area, but in some cases where something can be done, it should be done.Â Â And it seems Cornell understands that now and is taking action.Â
